Literature Review:
The integration of feedforward and feedback information streams in the modular architecture of mouse visual cortex has garnered significant attention in recent years. Radial cell columns, a hallmark feature of cortical architecture in many mammalian species, have been a subject of debate regarding their presence or absence in rodent primary visual cortex (V1). While it was initially thought that the lack of orientation columns in rodent V1 indicated the absence of radial cell columns, recent studies have revealed the presence of modular clusters of inputs to layer 1 and projection neurons in the layers below. These findings challenge the long-held view that rodent visual cortex has a fundamentally different network architecture than that of carnivores and primates.

In this review, we will discuss the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams in the mouse visual cortex, with a focus on the modular clusters of inputs to layer 1 and projection neurons. We will also examine the role of the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor in modulating thalamocortical inputs and intracortical processing streams.

The mouse visual cortex has been shown to exhibit a patchy connectivity pattern, with inputs to layer 1 and projection neurons organized into modular clusters (Bianchi et al., 2013). These modules have been found to organize thalamocortical inputs, intracortical processing streams, and transthalamic communications that underlie distinct sensory and sensorimotor functions (Kerr et al., 2015).

Studies have also demonstrated that the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor plays a crucial role in modulating thalamocortical inputs and intracortical processing streams in the mouse visual cortex (Wang et al., 2017). The activation of M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptors has been shown to enhance the excitability of thalamic neurons and promote the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams (Wang et al., 2017).

In addition to the role of the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, other studies have examined the processing hierarchy of the mouse visual cortex. Research has shown that the visual cortex exhibits a hierarchical processing structure, with early sensory areas processing basic visual features and later sensory areas processing more complex visual features (Kerr et al., 2015).

Furthermore, studies have investigated the role of layer 1 in the mouse visual cortex. Layer 1 has been found to play a critical role in the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams, with inputs to layer 1 and projection neurons organized into modular clusters (Bianchi et al., 2013).

In conclusion, the integration of feedforward and feedback information streams in the modular architecture of mouse visual cortex is a complex process that involves the coordinated activity of multiple neural populations. The role of the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, layer 1, and the processing hierarchy of the mouse visual cortex will be discussed in detail, highlighting the importance of these factors in modulating thalamocortical inputs and intracortical processing streams.
